sn56.35:1.1: “Mendicants, suppose there was a man with a lifespan of a hundred years.
sn56.35:1.2: And someone might say to him:
sn56.35:1.3: ‘Come now, my good man, they’ll strike you with a hundred spears in the morning, at midday, and in the late afternoon.
sn56.35:1.4: And you’ll live for a hundred years being struck with three hundred spears every day. But when a hundred years have passed, you will comprehend the four noble truths for the first time.’
sn56.35:2.1: For an earnest gentleman this is sufficient reason to submit.
sn56.35:2.4: No first point is found of blows by spears, swords, arrows, and axes.
sn56.35:2.6: But the comprehension of the four noble truths doesn’t come with pain or sadness, I say.
sn56.35:2.7: Rather, the comprehension of the four noble truths comes only with pleasure and happiness, I say.
sn56.35:2.9: The noble truths of suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
sn56.35:3.1: That’s why you should practice meditation …”
